word.entryDescription: an area of water that connects two larger areas of water
word.entryExample: The swallow leaves the white cliffs of Dover in England behind and flies over the English Channel.

word.entryDescription: a section of a book, usually with a number
word.entryExample: The title of the next chapter is: Disaster!

word.entryDescription: a symbol used in a system of writing
word.entryExample: Chinese has lots of complicated characters which makes it difficult to read.

word.entryDescription: the person in a story
word.entryExample: My favourite cartoon character is Dennis the Menace.

word.entryDescription: the set of qualities which make up someone's personality
word.entryExample: Name some of the aspects of your character that might be helpful in the new job.

word.entryDescription: to fill a battery with electricity
word.entryExample: You have to remember to check the battery level and charge your tablet if necessary before you watch a film.

word.entryDescription: to ask for a particular amount of money for something you are selling
word.entryExample: And look here! If we check in a bag, they'll charge us 20 euros! That's robbery!

word.entryDescription: to officially accuse somebody of a crime
word.entryExample: Two men were arrested and charged with a series of robberies in the Chiswick area.

word.entryDescription: to talk informally or exchange messages with a person or people over the internet
word.entryExample: He chats to Sue on the internet.

word.entryDescription: a person, especially a child, who talks a lot
word.entryExample: At the age of two, he hardly said a word, but now he's a little chatterbox.

word.entryDescription: not costing very much money
word.entryExample: The shops in New York are cheaper than the shops in Sam's town.

word.entryDescription: to show your ticket and hand over your luggage at an airport desk before getting on a plane; or to give your details at a hotel reception before you stay in a room
word.entryExample: You have to show your passports when you check in.

word.entryDescription: to give back your key and pay at a hotel reception before leaving
word.entryExample: Can I check out and pay by card? Thank you for the lovely stay.

word.entryDescription: to investigate
word.entryExample: I didn't know much about the World Cup so I checked out a few facts online.

word.entryDescription: a person working at the counter where you pay for the goods you have collected in a supermarket
word.entryExample: FreshCo's is looking for new check-out assistants to work in its town centre store.

word.entryDescription: an examination to make sure your body or your teeth are healthy
word.entryExample: Regular medical check-ups are a normal part of life in Japan.

word.entryDescription: happy or acting in a happy way
word.entryExample: He is amiable and welcomes everyone with a cheerful smile.

word.entryDescription: a solid yellow or white food made from milk
word.entryExample: My cat likes cheese.

word.entryDescription: a cake made from a mixture containing cream cheese
word.entryExample: Can I have a slice of cheesecake, please?

word.entryDescription: a large thin member of the cat family with yellow-brown fur and black spots, which can run very fast
word.entryExample: The cheetah is the fastest animal in the world.

word.entryDescription: a skilled cook, often the main cook in a restaurant
word.entryExample: Jake's ambition is to be a TV chef.

word.entryDescription: a person qualified to prepare and sell medicines (a pharmacist) or somebody who studies or works in the field of chemistry; chemist('s) is a shop that sells medicines, cosmetics, etc
word.entryExample: The doctor told him to go to the chemist's to get some medicine.

word.entryDescription: the study of the characteristics of substances and the way they combine with other substances
word.entryExample: We've got to revise for history, maths and chemistry.

word.entryDescription: a piece of paper you can use instead of money by writing on an amount and signing it
word.entryExample: Somebody posted the cheque this morning.

word.entryDescription: a board game for two players in which each player has pieces which can be moved in different ways
word.entryExample: I like to play chess with my friends.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body between your neck and your stomach
word.entryExample: He'll have his chest X-rayed for internal wounds tomorrow.

word.entryDescription: a box with a lid and usually a lock, used for storage or shipping
word.entryExample: In the 19th century wooden chests or crates were used to transport tea.

word.entryDescription: a piece of furniture with drawers in which you usually keep clothes
word.entryExample: I've got my school stuff on my bookshelves but I've also got a wardrobe and chest of drawers where I keep my clothes and sports gear.

word.entryDescription: a sweet that is often sold in a packet of thin strips, which you keep chewing but do not swallow
word.entryExample: Chewing gum can stick to people's shoes.

word.entryDescription: a young chicken; a very common bird that is farmed for its meat and eggs
word.entryExample: The baby chicks are one week old.

word.entryDescription: literature written particularly for women
word.entryExample: This novel is chick lit so I'll get it for my girlfriend.

word.entryDescription: a very common bird that people use for meat and eggs
word.entryExample: There's chicken for dinner.

word.entryDescription: not very cold but cold enough to feel uncomfortable
word.entryExample: It was a little chilly so I put on a jumper.

word.entryDescription: an African animal like a large monkey that has no tail and is very intelligent
word.entryExample: Chimpanzees are Man's closest relatives, and they can make tools for hammering, and for hunting other animals.

word.entryDescription: a very large east Asian country next to India
word.entryExample: A lot of tea comes from China.

word.entryDescription: of or from China or the language or people of China
word.entryExample: I'm learning Chinese because my company does a lot of business with China.

word.entryDescription: long thin pieces of potato which are fried in a lot of oil
word.entryExample: Would you like chips or salad with your burger?

word.entryDescription: a sweet brown solid food made from cocoa
word.entryExample: Jill likes chocolate.

word.entryDescription: the cover in which chocolate is packed in a chocolate factory
word.entryExample: The chocolate wrappers and crisp packets can't be recycled.

word.entryDescription: a group of singers usually in a church
word.entryExample: I used to sing in a choir when I was at school.

word.entryDescription: a fatty substance which exists in the blood and tissue of humans and animals, and which can cause heart disease if there is too much present
word.entryExample: Pet owners have lower cholesterol.

word.entryDescription: to decide which thing you want from a number of possibilities
word.entryExample: Please choose your ice cream - lemon or strawberry?

word.entryDescription: to cut into pieces
word.entryExample: First, wash the vegetables, grate the carrot and chop the parsley and spinach.

word.entryDescription: to make a tree or large plant fall down by cutting through it
word.entryExample: People have chopped all the trees down in this region.

word.entryDescription: a group of notes played together
word.entryExample: There is only a limited number of musical notes and chords, so it's not surprising that similarities can occur between different songs.

word.entryDescription: in Greek tragedy, an all-male cast of singers and dancers wearing masks, performing in a semi-circle known as an orchestra
word.entryExample: Originally a Greek chorus sang and danced.

word.entryDescription: a Christian festival around 25 December which is based on the birth of Christ
word.entryExample: Emma's aunt and uncle came to her house for Christmas.

word.entryDescription: put in order according to time or date
word.entryExample: The battles are listed in chronological order.

word.entryDescription: thick and heavy objects like rings, necklaces, etc worn as decoration
word.entryExample: I always wear my high-heeled boots and I love chunky jewellery.

word.entryDescription: a religious building for Christians
word.entryExample: You can cross the road next to the church.
